intro: Triumfetta pentandra var. pentandra, commonly known as the red sandmat, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and Australia. It is an annual herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring prostrate or ascending stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in clusters, which are followed by distinctive, inflated, bladder-like fruits. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and often have a hairy texture. The plant is adapted to arid and sandy soils, making it a common weed in disturbed areas.
